items.content:
#â€‹595 â€” May 31, 2023 | Read on the web

â–¶Â Â 21 Awesome Web Features Youâ€™re Not Using Yet? â€” Runs through some of the â€œgame changing new featuresâ€ that have landed on the web platform of late. Itâ€™s a good high-level run through of things delivered in a light-hearted, yet informativeÂ style. (8 minutes and a sense of humor required.)

Fireship

300ms Faster: Reducing Wikipedia's Total Blocking Time (TBT) â€” TBT is the sum of the blocking portion of long tasks on the main thread between First Contentful Paint (FCP) and Time to Interactive (TTI) â€” so lower is always better. The author got Wikipediaâ€™s TBT down by 300ms through small, targeted optimizations like removing an unnecessary JS call and using eventÂ delegation.

Nicholas Ray

Your CI, Secured â€” Build your dream CI/CD workflows without sharing your secrets or sourceÂ code.

Buildkite sponsor

SupportsCSS: Feature Detection for Modern CSS â€” Inspired by Modernizr, this little script expands on the capabilities of CSSâ€™s @supports feature by adding classes to your HTML and exposing a results object so you can run custom tests live in theÂ browser.

Stephanie Eckles

â–¶Â Â New in Chrome 114: text-wrap:balance, CHIPS, Popover API and More â€” Version 114 of Chrome is rolling out now and it has a few notable new features to be aware of, including text-wrap: balance (more on that here), the popover API, and changes to cookies. This quick five minute video runs through what you need toÂ know.

Adriana Jara (Google Chrome Developers)

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • WordPress is now 20 years old. Here's the original post from 2003 in which Matt Mullenweg shares the news of the first release. (And React is 10 years old. It must be the week for launching influential projects!)

  • Did you know that Safari supports a passwordrules attribute for finer control on password autofillÂ criteria?

  • The Web Share API (for sharing text, links and other content) is now a W3CÂ Recommendation.

  • Digital document format EPUB 3.3 is also now a W3C Recommendation.

  • ğŸ“— Addy Osmani has a new book on the way ("Success at Scale") covering best-practices 'at scale', unsurprisingly, in areas like performance, accessibility, andÂ DX.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Mastering CSS Blend Modes â€” CSS mix blend modes provide an easy, yet powerful way to create visually interesting designs, as explained here with clear cat-inspiredÂ visuals.

Koding Kitty

Announcing the Second 'Compute Pressure' Origin Trial â€” This new origin trial from Chrome allows web developers to monitor compute pressure (how hard the system is being worked to render the content on the current page) via the Computer PressureÂ API.

Christiansen & Mandy (Intel)

How to Scale a Complex React Native App? â€” Discover how to optimize development efficiency with superÂ apps.

Callstack sponsor

How to Draw Any Regular Shape with Just One JavaScript Function â€” Mozilla/MDN has a (relatively) new blog â€”Â here they share how to use JavaScript to draw any regular shape to a HTML canvas with a single function, and how to modify it to draw multipleÂ shapes.

Ruth John

A Brief Note on Popovers with Dialogs â€” When it comes to popovers and dialogs Adrian sees a potential issue for users â€œwhen developers mix and match theÂ patternsâ€.

Adrian Roselli

An FYI â€” display: contents Considered Harmful â€” â€œThe erratic nature of how the declaration actually functions [in practice] represents a very real, very serious risk of critical accessibility issues being introduced into your website or web app in a way that you have no controlÂ overâ€.

Eric Bailey

Error-Message Guidelines â€” Sound advice for designing effective error messages that deliver high visibility, provide constructive communication, and respect userÂ effort.

Neusesser & Sunwall (NNG)

Two Things That are Not Great About OKLCH â€” Color manipulation is..Â tricky.
Chris Coyier

Creating a 'Shine Effect' on a Card with Tailwind CSS
Julien Thibeaut

Wishlist: Single Line Comments in CSS
Jim Nielsen

Hired

BlockNote: A 'Notion-Like' Block-Based Text Editor â€” Flexible and presents an extensive API so you can integrate it with whatever you want to do. You can drag and drop blocks, add real-time collaboration, add customizable â€˜slash commandâ€™ menus, and more. Builds on top of ProseMirror andÂ TipTap.

TypeCell

Color Names: Large List of Handpicked ColorÂ Names â€” This goes beyond just the obvious choices like the named colors in HTML (ğŸ’œ rebeccapurple) â€” you'll actually find over 30,000 colors here with a delightful array of names and uses.

David Aerne

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Inkline 4.0: A Customizable Vue.js 3 UI/UX Library â€” A design system and numerous customizable components designed for mobile-first (but desktop friendly) and built with accessibility inÂ mind.

Alex Grozav

ls-lint 2.0: A Fast File and Directory Name Linter â€” Written in Go but aimed at JS/front-end dev use cases, ls-lint provides a way to enforce rules for file naming and directoryÂ structures.

Lucas LÃ¶ffel

Bootstrap 5.3.0: The Reponsive Sass-Based Frontend Toolkit â€” â€œa monumental effort to revamp our codebase for CSS variables and colorÂ modesâ€ â€“ including first class support for dark mode.

Mark Otto

Scroll-Driven Animation Examples â€” Thereâ€™s a bunch of neat demos here to show off scroll-driven animations in action that may get you thinking about how you can implementÂ them.

Bramus Van Damme

items.content:
#â€‹594 â€” May 24, 2023 | Read on the web

Introducing the popover API â€” Thereâ€™s a new set of declarative HTML APIs for building popovers on the way, and the first of which â€”Â the popover API â€” is landing in Chromium 114. This post shows us how to use it when building tooltips, menus, andÂ more. You're asking: Is this one of those Chrome/Edge-only experimental features for now? Yes. But MDN has docs, Safari is tech previewing it, and it may well takeÂ off.

Una Kravets (Chrome Developers)

Eleven HTML Best Practices for Login and Signup Forms â€” Andrey notes that â€œeven popular sites fail to implementâ€ the best practices highlighted in this article (such as autocomplete, focus states, validation, etc). Thereâ€™s a quick checklist towards the endÂ too.

Andrey Sitnik

Full Stack for Front-End Engineers with Jem Young (Netflix) â€” Learn what it means to become a well-rounded full-stack engineer with this hands-on video course. Youâ€™ll dive into servers, work with the command line, understand networking and security, set up continuous integration and deployment, manage databases, build containers, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

WebKit Features in Safari 16.5 â€” This version of Appleâ€™s browser contains a handful of new features including CSS Nesting, :user-valid and :user-invalid pseudo class support, Apple Pay changes, an update to cyber attack feature Lockdown Mode, the usual bug fixes andÂ more. Here's the release notes for the latest version of Safari Technology Preview too.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

'Why We're Bad at CSS' â€” â€œWe want our styles to be generic enough to reuse in different contexts but not so generic that we have to constantly repeat ourselves in those contextsâ€ â€”Â Mike explores how we may achieve this and improve things along the way, with a practicalÂ example.

Mike Aparicio

  • Jim Nielsen is proposing a 'well-known URL' specifically for avatars. "Think Gravatar but on a web where your domain is your social handle".

  • Use Sass? They're seeking feedback on a new embedded protocol.

Be Careful Using â€˜Menuâ€™ â€” Some cautionary advice on the use of the word â€˜menuâ€™ in your projects. Adrian warns us to be â€œcertain you have chosen the term that accurately describes the control youÂ wantâ€.

Adrian Roselli

We Built Our Documentation Using Docusaurus, React, andÂ Vercel â€” It requires effort to produce great documentation. Effective documentation is fundamental to users gettingÂ started.

courier.com sponsor

Add Opacity to an Existing Color â€” Letâ€™s say you have your brand color, and you want to find some nice complimentary opaque versions to go alongside it. What are your options? Chris runs through someÂ approaches.

Chris Coyier

â–¶Â Â The New dialog HTML Element Changes Modals Forever â€” This 12-minute video highlights how the dialog element can be used to create accessible modals â€”Â and there's a written version if youâ€™dÂ prefer. But...do you even need a modal?

Kyle (Web Dev Simplified)

The Button Case - Using Custom Properties for a Smart ButtonÂ System â€” A look at using variables in CSS to create an efficient button system (with just 20 lines of code thanks to customÂ properties).

Brecht De Ruyte

Updating My Website from My iPad â€” A look at using GitHub Codespaces to both develop and push updates to a site, all from anÂ iPad.

Daniel Diaz

â–¶Â Â Stop Rewriting Your CSS. Use :not() Instead â€” Useful stuff to know, especially as :not is supported everywhere.

Zoran Jambor

Temani Afif

Scroll Btween: Use Scroll Position to Tween CSS Values on DOMÂ Elements â€” Scrolling/parallax libraries tend to feel the same but this one demonstrates some diverse examples with colors, images, and text â€” all with noÂ dependencies.

Olivier Blanc

Windstatic: A Set of 170+ Components & Layouts Made with Tailwind and Alpine.js â€” Categorized under page sections, navigation, and forms, and each category includes multiple components you can drop into your TailwindÂ projects.

Michael Andreuzza

Picyard: Create Screenshots and Mockups with Beautiful Backgrounds â€” Has lots of different ways to customize including gradient backgrounds, shadows, dimensions, and you can even try out different kinds of mockups (testimonials, code snippets, etc).

Alan

Starry Night: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting â€” GitHubâ€™s own syntax highlighting approach isnâ€™t open source, but this takes a similar approach. Itâ€™s admittedly quite heavy (due to using a WASM build of the Oniguruma regex engine) but if you want something with the sameÂ experience..

Titus Wormer

items.title: What you need to know from Google I/O
items.content:
#â€‹593 â€” May 17, 2023 | Read on the web

Conditional CSS with :has and :nth-last-child â€” Highlights a few practical examples of combining the CSS selector :nth-last-child with :has to create dynamic components and layoutÂ states. Lots of great visuals and code examples here to help things along.

Ahmad Shadeed

A Complete Guide to Performance Budgets â€” If youâ€™ve invested a lot of time to make sure that your site is as fast as it can be, youâ€™ll benefit from having some things in place to prevent regressions. Tammy Everts walks through the idea of a â€˜performance budgetâ€™, which metrics to track, and how to focus on the things that trulyÂ matter.

Tammy Everts (Speedcurve)

How to Dynamically Filter Angular Grid FromÂ Code â€” While the Kendo UI for Angular Grid comes with built-in filtering functionality, sometimes you need to allow users to control what the filters show. We can do that too. Letâ€™s take aÂ look.

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Introducing Baseline â€” A new initiative (announced at Google I/O) to help you quickly see whether a feature or API is safe to use in your site or web apps. This post shares details on the ideas that led to the concept, and how it willÂ help. Here's another post on how you can use Baseline today.

Rachel Andrew (Chrome Developers)

Zoran Jambor has done a quick â–¶ï¸ six-minute video sharing what you need to know about Baseline, caling it "a new way to think about browser support".

ğŸ”‘ Spotlight On.. Passkeys â€” Three early adopters (from Kayak, Robinhood, and Instacart) share their thoughts on this new security technology, having rolled it out on theirÂ platforms. â–¶ï¸ Also, there was a roughly 20-minute talk at Google I/O last week in which Eiji Kitamura showed us how you can make use of this new security feature. (ğŸ¤” Still trying to make sense of Passkeys? This recent post from MichaÅ‚ Sapka may help.)

Apple Developer

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • ğŸ’¡ DevTools Tips is a handy site filled with a growing collection of bitesize browser dev tool tutorials.

  • â–¶ï¸ Here's Una Kravets with a quick web-focused round-up of what was announced at Google I/O last week, including WebGPU, new CSS features, and privacy changes.

  • In an effort to improve UX, there's an intial proposal for shared-autofill across iframes.

  • WebGPU support now sits at over 40%, mostly thanks to Chrome's rapidÂ rollout.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

What's New in CSS and UI: I/O 2023 Edition â€” Yes, more from I/O. This time it's the top 20 CSS and UI features highlighted at the show that you â€œdonâ€™t want toÂ missâ€ â€” including, nesting, scoped CSS (see below), popover, scroll-driven animations, and more. This post is packed withÂ stuff.

Chrome Developers

Scoped CSS is Back â€” Back, and better than before, the W3C spec is stable, and you can now test things under a flag in Chrome. What is it? Well, scope is â€œa game changerâ€ that brings more control over which selectors target which elements, and the ability for one set of styles to override another based on proximity in theÂ DOM.

Keith J. Grant

â–¶Â Â Whatâ€™s New in Web Animations â€” A talk from the recent Google I/O conference covering view transition, scroll-driven animations, easing curves, and individual transform properties (17-minutes).

Bramus Van Damme

React Authentication, Simplified â€” In this article, we lay out a new approach to authentication (plus access control & SSO) in ReactÂ applications.

Userfront sponsor

Advancing Interaction to Next Paint (INP) â€” The Chrome team has announced that INP is no longer experimental and will replace First Input Delay (FID) as a Core Web Vital inÂ 2024.

Viscomi & Sullivan

Semantics and the popover Attribute: What to Use When? â€” The experimental popover HTML attribute adds behavior, not semantics. Hidde asks which semantics should you use in combination with thisÂ attribute?

Hidde de Vries

How We Built the Storybook Day 3D Animation â€” Have you ever seen an impressive animation and wondered â€˜so howâ€™d they actually do that?â€™ This tutorial takes the Storybook Day animation and breaks it down step-by-step, each with sampleÂ code.

Varun Vachhar
